channel.title: RNZ Covid-19 Headlines
channel.description: The Latest Covid-19 headlines from RNZ News

item.title: Covid-19 wrap: 33 new cases as part of Waikato hit with a lockdown
item.description: Part of Waikato is joining Auckland in alert level 3; at least one testing station was swamped and Air New Zealand announces a 'no jab, no fly' policy.

item.title: Prime minister slates Destiny Church over 'illegal, morally wrong' gathering
item.description: The protest hosted by Destiny Church leader Brian Tamaki yesterday was "a slap in the face" for Aucklanders who were complying with level 3 rules, the prime minister says.

item.title: Live Covid-19 updates for 3 October - everything you need to know
item.description: People are being turned away from a Waikato testing centre, despite being urged by the PM and Director General of Health to get tested. See how the day's news unfolded with RNZ's blog.

item.title: Covid-19 briefing: Waikato joins Auckland in alert level 3 from tonight
item.description: Parts of Waikato - including Raglan, Huntly, Ngāruawāhia and Hamilton City - will join Auckland in alert level 3 from midnight tonight, the Prime Minister has confirmed. Watch the latest government briefing here.

item.title: Covid-19 update: 33 new community cases reported in New Zealand
item.description: There have been 33 new community cases of Covid-19 reported in New Zealand today, with 15 still to be linked to earlier cases.

item.title: Air NZ to introduce 'no jab, no fly' policy for global flights
item.description: Air New Zealand is introducing a 'no jab, no fly' policy for international travellers, starting in February next year.

item.title: Two new Covid-19 community cases reported in Waikato
item.description: Two new Covid-19 cases have been reported in Waikato, with "a number of exposure events" the Ministry of Health has confirmed this morning.

item.title: Auckland truck driver who visited Manawatū tests positive
item.description: Thirteen new locations of interest including service stations, a supermarket and a Burger King are among locations of interest after an Auckland truck driver who travelled to Palmerston North tests positive.

item.title: Melbourne's lockdown world record as state records 1220 new cases
item.description: Victoria has recorded 1220 new cases of Covid-19 and three deaths on the eve of Melbourne becoming the most locked down city in the world.

item.title: Bordering on fear and hate: Vitriol aimed at returnees heartbreaking
item.description: Opinion - For a country whose mantras are "be kind" and the "team of 5 million", where is the kindness and inclusivity, asks returnee [Angus Simmons].

item.title: Covid-19 data visualisations: NZ in numbers
item.description: Track how Auckland's move to level 3 is impacting the Covid outbreak with the latest case numbers, testing and vaccination data in New Zealand.

item.title: Covid-19 vaccines: New Zealand’s most Googled questions answered
item.description: From how many people are vaccinated to how many types of Covid vaccines there are, we set out to answer New Zealanders' most Googled Covid-19 vaccine questions.

item.title: Covid-19: Another exposure event at Middlemore Hospital's ED
item.description: Middlemore Hospital has reported another possible exposure event, after a person who went to the emergency department last night later tested positive for Covid-19.

item.title: Covid-19 in focus: New cases stabilise, but govt urges caution
item.description: New Covid-19 numbers remain static, alarm as patients coming into Middlemore Hospital test positive, and the government urges caution in Auckland this weekend.

item.title: 'It's soul-destroying': Northland expects to be hit hard as Auckland border stays
item.description: Businesses in Te Tai Tokerau are feeling the strain as Auckland's border keeps visitors at bay.

item.title: Henare says he's having 'uncomfortable conversations' about Māori vaccination rates
item.description: Whānau Ora minister Peeni Henare has met with iwi health providers from across Te Tai Tokerau in Whangārei to talk about lagging Māori vaccination rates.

item.title: Covid-19 briefing: 'We must not get complacent' - deputy PM
item.description: Covid-19 case numbers may be "relatively stable", but NZ can't afford to get complacent, says the deputy PM, who is urging Aucklanders to get tested this weekend. Watch the latest government briefing here.

item.title: Police clear crowds gathered at West Auckland funeral home
item.description: A large crowd of gang members and other mourners were moved on by police from a funeral home in West Auckland this afternoon.

item.title: Global Covid-19 deaths hit 5 million as Delta variant sweeps the world
item.description: Worldwide deaths related to Covid-19 have surpassed 5 million, according to a Reuters tally, with unvaccinated people particularly exposed to the virulent Delta strain.

item.title: UK food banks brace for halted Covid-19 payments, higher gas prices
item.description: Food banks in the UK are "preparing for the worst" as the government starts winding up measures put in place to cushion the pandemic's impact on millions of workers and low-income households.

item.title: With petrol pumps still dry, Britain brings in the army
item.description: The UK is set to deploy military tanker drivers to deliver fuel to gas stations, many of which are still dry after a chaotic week that has seen panic-buying and fights at the pumps.

item.title: Covid-19 vaccinations: More than 50 nations have missed a target set by WHO
item.description: More than 50 countries have missed the World Health Organisation's (WHO) target for 10 percent of their populations to be fully vaccinated against Covid-19 by the end of September.

item.title: Covid antiviral pill can halve risk of hospitalisation
item.description: An experimental drug for severe Covid cuts the risk of hospitalisation or death by about half, interim clinical trial results suggest.

item.title: Covid:19: Victoria records highest daily increase with 1488 new cases
item.description: Victoria has recorded 1488 new cases of Covid-19 and two deaths, marking the highest ever daily increase in cases for the state.

item.title: Australian border to reopen next month
item.description: Prime Minister Scott Morrison has announced the international border will reopen next month for states that have reached 80 percent vaccination rates, starting with New South Wales.

item.title: Farmer who contracted Covid-19 urges public to get vaccinated
item.description: Some farmers impacted by one of last year's Covid-19 clusters are encouraging people to get vaccinated, no matter where they live in the country.

item.title: Covid-19 update: 19 new community cases, just one unlinked
item.description: Just one of the new cases reported today is yet to be linked, the Ministry of Health says.

item.title: Covid-19 updates: Middlemore case moved into isolation
item.description: The Covid-19 case who discharged themselves from Middlemore Hospital is now being moved to a quarantine facility. See how the day's Covid-19 news unfolded with RNZ's live blog.

item.title: Victoria records 1143 new Covid-19 cases and three deaths
item.description: Childcare centres across Melbourne were identified as tier 1 exposure sites, with new exposure sites also appearing regionally in Ararat, Geelong and Warrnambool.

item.title: No staff or facilities for 'catching up' on delayed surgery, surgeon says
item.description: Orthopaedic surgeons say it may be impossible to ever "catch up" on all the operations delayed due to the Covid-19 restrictions.

item.title: Middlemore Hospital deals with 'quite a flurry' of Covid-19 cases
item.description: Middlemore Hospital dealt with six patients with Covid on Wednesday night, including two who turned up at the emergency department and later tested positive.

item.title: Hard up tourist operators want wage subsidy extended after Auckland decision
item.description: The tourism sector is asking for a continuation of the wage subsidy, even if Auckland moves down to level 2.

item.title: Community ties essential to contain 'aggressive' tail-end of Delta - Minister for Pacific Peoples
item.description: Some people becoming ill with Covid-19 have never engaged with the health system before, says Minister for Pacific Peoples Aupito William Sio.

item.title: Auckland Hospital rapidly preparing for border reopening
item.description: Auckland Hospital is preparing to deal with an average of six Covid deaths a week next year, even with a 90 percent vaccination rate.

item.title: Educators 'not surprised' by drop in NCEA pass marks
item.description: Teenagers are ending the third school term today with 93,000 fewer NCEA pass marks than at the same time last year.

item.title: Covid-19 exposure risk at Middlemore Hospital after two patients test positive
item.description: Sixty-six patients at Middlemore Hospital have been potentially exposed to Covid-19 after two patients with the virus presented to the emergency department.

item.title: Covid-19 in focus: Developments on 30 September
item.description: There was a significant drop of community cases, more subclusters form in Auckland, and migrant workers will be able to apply for fast-track residency.

item.title: MIQ taking toll on returnees' mental health - psychologists
item.description: Psychologists say there's emerging evidence of long-term and in some cases 'severe' effects from time spent in MIQ.

item.title: Medsafe believes Pfizer vaccine not factor in death of teen
item.description: Medsafe has recorded the death of a 17-year-old following their first Covid-19 vaccine but it believes the dose was not a factor.

item.title: Auckland boundary likely to remain even if alert level drops
item.description: Aucklanders are being told even if there's a shift in alert levels next week, the regional boundary will likely remain along with some other restrictions.

item.title: Covid-19 briefing: Govt still has 'broad control' of Auckland outbreak - PM Jacinda Ardern
item.description: Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern says the government still has "broad control" of the Covid-19 Delta outbreak in Auckland. Watch the latest government briefing here.

item.title: Covid-19 updates: New case outside Auckland
item.description: One of today's 19 new community cases of Covid-19 is outside Auckland, with a student in northern Hauraki testing positive. See how the day's Covid-19 news developed with RNZ's blog.

item.title: Many disabled people being failed by vaccine rollout, supporters say
item.description: Health authorities are accused of failing to help of thousands of disabled people who can't easily travel but need access to the Covid-19 vaccine.

item.title: Covid-19 update: 19 new community cases today
item.description: Director-General of Health Ashley Bloomfield says they're expecting another 30 or so cases in the coming days from day five and day 12 testing.

item.title: South Island tourism operators relying on Auckland bookings await level update
item.description: South Island tourism operators are crossing their fingers ahead of the October school holidays as they wait to hear if Aucklanders can travel again.

item.title: Vaccine passports 'effective' for fans at events but gyms worried over staff abuse
item.description: The government plans to have technology for Covid-19 vaccine passports available in just over a month, which could be required for live events, venues and other services.

item.title: Proposed vaccine passport significantly flawed - ministry insider
item.description: Vaccine certificates are likely to be granted to people without a person needing any actual proof they've been vaccinated.

item.title: Man who fled Covid-19 border stopped by road spikes 50km away
item.description: Police used road spikes and an Eagle helicopter to catch a driver who fled a police checkpoint at the Auckland border yesterday.

item.title: Covid-19 vaccination incentives tried as numbers for first dose drop
item.description: Only a quarter of the number that were going for their first shot in early September have been rolling up their sleeves this week and incentives are being used in South Auckland from today.

item.title: Covid-19 team helps Auckland families frightened of being tested
item.description: A Covid-19 testing team working with families in emergency housing says many are frightened about being tested and the possibility of being separated.

item.title: Government offers one-off visa to fast-track skilled migrant residency
item.description: The government is setting up a one-off resident visa includes more than 5000 health and aged care workers and 9000 primary industry workers.

item.title: Woman suffering long Covid still can't smell or taste a year later
item.description: It has been more than a year since Melbourne woman Eleanor was diagnosed with Covid-19, and she still can't smell or taste.

item.title: Covid-19: Record 1438 cases in Victoria, 941 in NSW
item.description: Victoria has recorded 1438 new locally acquired cases of Covid-19 and five further deaths, while New South Wales has recorded 941 cases and six deaths.

item.title: 'We cannot continue locking New Zealand up' - Collins on National's Covid-19 strategy
item.description: National Party leader Judith Collins says life is full of risks and the country can't keep going into lockdown to keep Covid-19 at bay.

item.title: Government unable to reveal cost of MIQ subsidies for sports teams
item.description: Officials don't know how much they've splashed out on MIQ subsidies for international sports teams.

item.title: Parliament goes into urgency over Covid-19 response bill
item.description: Parliament went into urgency this afternoon, for the first reading of legislation making a raft of changes as part of the Covid-19 response.

item.title: No holiday visitors for Auckland leaves struggling businesses disappointed
item.description: There will be no school holiday ski-trips or whānau visits for Aucklanders across the regional Covid-19 border, with the Prime Minister's confirmation that the city will remain shut-off from the rest of the country regardless of a drop in alert levels.

item.title: Port workers' 95% vaccination rate attributed to tackling misinformation
item.description: A turnaround in the number of port workers vaccinated is being attributed to success in tackling misinformation and making it mandatory for those on the border's frontline.

item.title: MIQ should include priority system - law expert
item.description: An Otago University law professor says there's a need for a prioritisation system within MIQ bookings, with people left waiting over a year to be granted entry to the country.

item.title: Covid-19 in focus: Developments on 29 September
item.description: Auckland case numbers spike, National Party calls for end to lockdowns and Police and Navy investigate staff for crossing Auckland boundary without exemption.
